title: Tuesday, 22nd May, 2018
bodyHTML:
AAAA Bonjour les amis !
11:04 am
BE11:05am

Hey. Good morning, hello, hi there.

Manxish Morning internet peoples
AAAA Salut Bryce !
Soundbuy Morning all
BE11:06am

Remember the good old days when we'd have a few hours to prepare for this thing?

Paper Chase Hullo.
BE11:07am

The days when I didn't have to file 1k words for online before even opening the Markets Live page? Anyway.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

What'll we do for a picture today? Let's stop over at the Shadow POTUS.

BE11:07am

https://twitter.com/kanyewest/status/998642119123206144?s=20

cleverhedge Bryce! did you see my tweet about the Rotork upgrade/downgrade yesterday?
Plato the Cook Seid gegrüsst
BE11:08am

Kanye tweeting Adam Curtis.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

(@cleverhedge: I did, and replied, and fixed it. Thank you.)

Paper Chase Who's Sigmund Frued?
rise2010 The Times: RBS considers restarting dividends on scale that will rival Lloyds
FATDAZ @BE thats a frightening combination
BE11:09am

Not sure anything could be more 2018 than Kanye tweeting Adam Curtis.

cleverhedge @BE replied to me?
BE11:09am

(@rise2010: wasn't that yesterday?)

Lemmy What is Kanye?
FATDAZ @rise2010 what will it pay dividends out of ??
GBKrona Jambo
Flaneur @Lemmy - Kanye West is a resort on the Florida Keys, I think.
rise2010 @BE - looks like it was @FATDAZ - excess capital?
11:10 am
BE11:10am

What's also 2018 is the FTSE continuing to motor higher for no clear reason.

BE11:10am

Other than sterling, of course.

BE11:11am

Up another 0.1% this morning, awaiting Carney.

chopper bear sterling's up ?
FATDAZ Adam Curtis has some interesting points to make in the power of nightmares an all watched over by machines of loving grace but may have lost his way lately IMHO
11:11 am
BE11:12am

If anyone wants to send me a canned quote about how the FTSE passing through 8k will be psychologically important, feel free.

undefined
FATDAZ @rise2010 my point is I don't believe it has amy excess capital and effectively owes the Gov £80 billion ??
FATDAZ just saying
BE11:13am

Oh -- I forgot to mention that the FTSE 100's still down 25% from its 2007 high if you price it in dollars, and is quite a bit off its January high under the same measure.

patatbat atc na.. whats the story there?
11:13 am
BE11:14am

But let's not get bogged down on that. To corporate.

BE11:14am

(@patatbat: don't speak in codes please. It's ex div on the US spinoff.)

BE11:15am

And, hey look, it's another bunch of terrible numbers from Pets at Home.

11:14 am
Pets at Home Group PLC (PETS:LSE): Last: 145.58, down 12.42 (-7.86%), High: 165.80, Low: 144.30, Volume: 3.52m
BE11:15am

The big news here is that they've broken out the vets JV stuff for the first time.

Excel Developer FTSE100 : heading towards 8000
Peace and Love @paperchase Sigmund Frued was a terrible impersonator of the better known Sigmund Freud d'apres Wikpedai
BE11:16am

You'll remember the concerns around the vets JVs, which seem to consume a massive amount of cash and quite often fail.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Pets has to write loans to practices just to keep them going.

BE11:17am

So ...... today we get Pets breaking out £29m of profit for the division in YE 2018.

BE11:18am

Except it doesn't, because against that there's £15m of operating loans

11:17 am
PM11:18am

(Morning -- sorry I'm so late)

hornblower any comment on Greencore? another short squeeze?
BE11:18am

And guidance for a further £20m working capital outflow this year

BE11:18am

Plus a £5m bad debt provision for YE2019 against these operating loans

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Also, the target for opening vet practices has fallen to 20-25 in the year ahead, from 50 previously.

PM11:19am

Why is the vets side so problematic? (Behind the curve on Pets)

BE11:20am

Well, we've talked a bit here about the peculiarities of the vet market.

Tom Dalgleish The suggestion with Greencross Vets in Australia is that mobile vets are eating into bricks and mortar revenue
11:20 am
PM11:20am

Vets are like dentists

PM11:21am

But sorry, go on

BE11:21am

Partly, though arguably the service is rather higher. And there aren't many places where economies of scale really work for stuff like out-of-hours services, so consolidation doesn't always work.

11:21 am
PM11:21am

ok

Excel Developer @PM: "vets are like dentists", rather not get a filling at a vet, they might castrate me by accident.
Tom Dalgleish A recent survey showed that vet numbers are rising much faster than industry revenue
Patience @PM - customers discovering that their local vet surgery is cheaper than Pets-at-home instore surgery?
Paper Chase @peace Ah yes! Brother of the terribly ill-mannered Sigmund Frude,
BE11:22am

We've talked a bit in the past about how vets need to keep growing or they just kind of stall and turn into the kind of family practices that are available to the consolidators.

Tom Dalgleish @Patience, ditto, Greencross had trouble in the stores. Threw away their grandiose plans
BE11:23am

I'd find it in the archive if the archive, if we had one. Instead, read this summary of a very good note from Geoff Rudell at MOST: https://www.ft.com...-b7e0-52972418fec4

11:23 am
BE11:24am

More than two-thirds of the practices made an operating loss last year and “many appear to be reliant on Pets at Home lending them money”, with the retailer writing £20m of operating loans to joint ventures over the past 18 months, said Morgan Stanley. Many of the practices opened in recent years appear not to be generating enough cash to meet debt repayments, it said.

FATDAZ @BE we have used the Ocado sister company Fetch ( pet supplies etc ) several time recently suspect thats something to watch as n emerging competitive threat to pets at home
BE11:24am

Course, Pets itself blames a shortage of vets for the reduced expansion plans.

BE11:25am

Hang on, let me get the Goldman summary of the guidance.

Flaneur Never understand why people have animals in their houses. Or how they have emotional relationships with them; why a dog and not a squirrel? Doesnt make sense.
11:25 am
BE11:25am

Guidance: Pets at Home expects FY19 expects gross margin to decline 75-125bps (GSe -60bps, consensus -50bps) and operating cost to increase by 3-3.5%. It also expects to open up to five superstores (GSe +9), 20-25 vet practices (GSe +40) and 10-20 grooming salons (GSe +25). Within the veterinary business, the lower space roll-out is associated with continued challenges in the supply of veterinarians. Other guidance includes D&A £37-38mn (GSe £36.7mn), Net Interest £3-3.5mn (GSe £4.3mn), 20% effective tax rate, capex £39-41mn (GSe £39mn) and a working capital outflow of c£20mn.

Otter Hello tuesday friends
BE11:25am

Plus a margin hit.

BE11:26am

Pets at Home (PAH) reported FY18 results with PBT of £84.5mn (-12.3% yoy, company-complied consensus £84.3mn, GSe £85.2mn), in-line with consensus expectations. FY18 Group LFL sales growth was +5.5% (consensus +5%), split services +8.5% (consensus +8.7%) and merchandising +5% (consensus +4.2%). Pets continues to benefit from a significant acceleration in merchandising LFL, reflecting a strong pick-up in omnichannel and volume uplift due to price changes driving market share gains in food and accessories. The gross margin declined by 250bp (consensus -220bps, GSe -235bps) to 51.7% in FY18 as it invests in own brands as well as branded products (in FY18, PAH invested c£13mn in pricing).

Flaneur ...or an otter.
FATDAZ @flanneur in this instance suspect you are in the minority
Soundbuy Easier to take a dog for a walk than a squirrel for a climb?
Lemmy Flaneur: you try teaching a squirrel to sit/fetch ;-)
Badger @flaneur. Dogs don't normally go for your nuts
Lefevre @Fatdaz, totally agree Adam Curtis has lost his way a little, but Century of the Self was v good - Kanye should put down his twitter & try the full 4 hours..
FATDAZ @lefevere thanks may try to watch it myself in bite sized pieces
11:27 am
BE11:27am

@Flaneur: Schopenhauer, Studies in Pessimism, chapter two. I'd expect you of all people to know that ffs.

Peace and Love @paperchase himself and the great grand father of Sigourney Feaver. Some family!
Excel Developer Dogs are brilliant.
undefined
Patience @Flaneur - having a pet reduces blood pressure and heart rate. Important for some of us :-(
BE11:28am

Otherwise in retail, we have Halfords being Halfords.

Soundbuy Until you get a vet's bill.........
pancakes or waffles If you had to be one animal, what would you be
Excel Developer @Soundbuy: insurance?
11:28 am
Halfords Group PLC (HFD:LSE): Last: 343.60, down 44.4 (-11.44%), High: 351.20, Low: 329.40, Volume: 1.83m
PM11:28am

Scorchedfingers

patatbat zooplus is the pure online pet supply play
Soundbuy Only got fire and theft :)
Swedish Chef @excel The Koreans agree. Happily ear horse but draw the (illogical) line at Fido. Or guinea pigs in Peru.
BE11:29am

new guy in charge says no profit uplift next year. Consensus expected 7%.

Excel Developer @pancakes: lion
11:28 am
BE11:29am

Three reasons:

Flaneur (@BE - 'A pessimist is what a fantasist calls a realist.' - Whoever)
FATDAZ @Soundbuy having seen the care and attention our dog gets from the Vet I would be happy for them to treat me in preference to local GPs
Lemmy patatbat: yes and a Rocket Internet success at that too
pancakes or waffles @Excel but lions are hunted by humans and close to extinction
BE11:29am

First, and least interestingly, the expected benefit of weak £ has been kicked into 2020.

pancakes or waffles though it would be pretty cool admittedly
Plato the Cook @pancakes: human
BE11:30am

Second, another load of cash on staff training and marketing and stuff like that.

FATDAZ @BE re Halfords no scope for more volume / profits on new MOT tests / standards then ?
pancakes or waffles @Plato obviously in this theoretical scenario, we are excluding humans :)
11:30 am
BE11:30am

Third, a difficult end quarter for bikes. As a result, Halfords has scrapped its plans to hike bike prices this year.

Plato the Cook @pancakes the royal we?
BE11:31am

Is Halfords losing market share there?

Soundbuy Just an observation but the second-hand bike market seems totally rammed........
Swedish Chef Staff training useful at Halfords. Ever tried asking for a bycycle part there? The owner manager at your local bike shop is the way to go.
BE11:32am

From online, obv, but also from the likes of Decathlon, which seems to undercut Halfords' own brands quite considerably.

Manxish @pancakes a seal
Excel Developer wtf is the Schopenahuer reference?
11:32 am
PM11:32am

Decathlon opening all over the place

Flaneur Bike sales are 1) very weather sensitive 2) very UK-doing-well-in-some-event sensitive.
BE11:33am

@Soundbuy, also, makes a good point. Ebay growth is probably bad news for Halfords as well.

wayneJ Surely, Bryce would have a Porsche bike - https://shop1.porsche.com/uk/sport/bike/wap06101x0g/porsche-bike-rs-black-lavaorange.pdds
FATDAZ speaking of human interaction with animals and nature this was very depressing reading https://amp.theguardian.com/environment/2018/may/21/human-race-just-001-of-all-life-but-has-destroyed-over-80-of-wild-mammals-study
Otter how much is second hand bike ?
BE11:34am

The loss of pricing power is hardly surprising really. The surprise was that it wasn't highlighted by previous management.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Let me grab some grey for what's happening to forecasts.

Swedish Chef A lot of the merchandise on sale at the likes of Halfords are more accurately described as bycycle shaped objects. A spanner reveals they are made of plastercene
BE11:35am

Here's Stifel.

Excel Developer do people trust self driving cars to spot and avoid cyclists?
BE11:35am

The main surprise today is that management is guiding to FY19 PBT unchanged on FY18 "broadly in line with FY18" - vs our expectations of £82.9m and consensus of £76.5m. This reflects later phasing of the FX benefit (into FY20) and an acceleration of investment (services proposition and in customer relationships and data) following the arrival of the new CEO. We also suspect the new management team would be reluctant to preside over strong profit growth in the first year and stable profits thereafter.

wayneJ Or Gucci bike - https://gizmodo.com/5885919/14000-gucci-bike-is-an-urban-commuter-for-one-percenters
11:35 am
BE11:35am

The stock rallied to the top of the trading range in the run-up to the results and we recently reduced our rating to Hold. Weaker profit guidance should see profit-taking today. On new guidance of unchanged c.EPS 29.6p - FY19 P/E rises to c.13.1x at last night's close. With the dividend and balance sheet still solid, we would expect to see support at around 330p (5.5% yield). The shares remain an attractive option for income investors in our view.

FATDAZ @excel do you trust yourself ? they way they rise in London is frightening some times I say that as pedestrian onlooker
BE11:36am

Or, more briefly, Canaccord.

FATDAZ ride in london
BE11:36am

11:36 am

Yep.

BE11:39am

Thumbs up

tangledodyssey Decathlon started with a store in Lille, France in 1976, founded by Michel Leclercq. It started to expand abroad a decade later, to Germany in 1986, Spain in 1992, Italy in 1998, Portugal, the United Kingdom in 1999, China in 2003, India in 2009, Malaysia in 2016 and Southeast Asia in 2012 and South Africa, Philippines in 2017 and Australia in 2018. Today, there are more than 1100 stores[4] in 38 countries. The company employs more than 78,000 staff[5] from 80 different nationalities.from wiki profile
11:39 am
PM11:39am

Retail Week revealed yesterday three internal changes to its senior team with regard to the executive committee level, just below the Group Board. Tony Hoggett returns to the UK in a new role as Group Chief Operating Officer to help run the core chain’s stores. We recently updated our forecasts and revisited the investment thesis in our Tesco note – Building credibility and potential. We believe that the Group can consolidate upon its recent recovery, weave Booker into the wider business, stay focused in the face of whatever emerges with respect to Sainsbury's^ (SBRY, Hold at 316p) proposed 'merger' with Asda (Wal-Mart, WMT, NYSE, NR CNP) and correspondingly deliver strong EPS growth, considerable free cash flows and even more robust DPS distribution. At the same time we believe that ongoing deleveraging can bolster the stock rating. We reiterate our BUY rating

Pretty short

tangledodyssey halfords should be concerned

Inmarsat PLC (ISAT:LSE): Last: 344.40, down 44.2 (-11.37%), High: 371.50, Low: 335.30, Volume: 5.81m

Excel Developer @waynej: I agree, they probably have some sort of neural network or some such that is radically different from object orientation (with its useful bug proof encapsulation)

So, Inmarsat loses its monopoly on the world shipping distress thing

11:45 am
BE11:45am

The UN approves Iridium Communications, which has been lobbying for entry into the market for at least five years

Sails Indeed @Otter about cyclists on zebra crossings. When I come to power such offenders will be executed on the spot

This looks to be seriously bad news for Inmarsat

Sails (And I say that as a cyclist)
SoS No announcement from inmarsat
11:46 am
BE11:46am

Well, yes-ish and no-ish.

BE11:46am

Here's RBC.

BE11:46am

Although Inmarsat does not earn revenue directly from GMDSS (either service or hardware), the monopoly confers an advantage as it requires all ships over 300 gross tonnes to carry Inmarsat terminals. Inmarsat can then offer commercial voice and data services over its terminals. Iridium is likely to provide GMDSS service from early 2020.

luzh I can't believe anything using a neural network that hasn't been thoroughly unit tested would be allowed to operate on our roads.
A. M. @luzh: does the manual's small^n-print says something like "an initial period of acclimatization, in which minor prangs may happen, is to be expected"?
Excel Developer @luzh: indeed, how can a neural network but proven to be bug-free? Its logic is by definition fuzzy.
FATDAZ re ISAT and Iridium aren't the both likely to be under threat from low cost low orbit competitors / space entrepreneurs
11:47 am
BE11:47am

It's a defacto monopoly, interestingly.

PM11:48am

hmm

BE11:48am

GMDSS does not generate any revenues for Inmarsat, as the service is free to use and the hardware/terminals are provided by third parties. However, all large ship owners are compelled to have GMDSS systems on board, which means Inmarsat is onboard every large commercial ship. This means a ship owner has a choice – either to use the (GMDSS approved) Inmarsat terminal for voice and data or to install an extra satellite
system for voice and data leaving the Inmarsat system for emergencies only).  Clearly, losing the monopoly lowers the barrier to entry for Iridium long
term.

jaws Any thing in IWG plc please ?
Excel Developer self-driving acceptable on motorways where no cyclists and clear monotonous lane driving.
11:48 am
BE11:49am

Okay, so maritime's 40% and 60% of 2017 revenues and EBITDA respectively for Inmarsat.
